step1.sentence: She decided to take up painting after she retired from her teaching career.

step2.story: After years of watching cooking shows, Mark finally decided to take up baking. His first attempt at sourdough bread was a disaster, but he refused to give up. Within a few months, his homemade pastries became the highlight of every family gathering.

step3.story: Jina had always admired the rock climbers at the gym near her office, watching them scale the walls during her lunch breaks. One rainy Monday, feeling stuck in her routine, she walked in and signed up for a beginner class. She was terrified at first — her arms trembled and her palms were slick with sweat. But the instructor smiled and said everyone starts somewhere, and that was enough to keep her going. By the end of the month, she had taken up climbing as a serious hobby, spending every weekend at the crag. It didn't just take up her free time — it completely transformed the way she saw challenges in her everyday life.

meaning.literalMeaningKo: 'take'(가져가다) + 'up'(위로) → 무언가를 집어 올리다, 위로 가져가다라는 뜻에서 출발합니다.
meaning.realUsageKo: 실제로는 두 가지 핵심 의미로 쓰입니다. 첫째, 새로운 활동이나 취미를 '시작하다'(I took up yoga). 둘째, 공간이나 시간을 '차지하다'(This sofa takes up too much room).
meaning.etymologyKo: 고대 영어에서 '집어 올리다'라는 물리적 동작에서 비롯되어, 중세 영어 시기에 '새로운 일을 손에 들다 → 시작하다'라는 비유적 의미로 확장되었습니다.
meaning.nuanceKo: '시작하다' 의미로 쓸 때는 단순한 시도가 아니라 어느 정도 진지하게 시작한다는 뉘앙스가 있습니다. 'start'보다 의지와 지속성이 느껴지는 표현입니다.
meaning.shortExampleEn: The new bookshelf takes up half of my room.
meaning.shortExampleKo: 새 책장이 내 방의 절반을 차지한다.
